conclusion: To determine whether the amount of heat absorbed is greater than or less than the amount of heat released during a complete cycle of the ideal gas, we need to analyze the processes shown in the p-V diagram.

The diagram shows two adiabatic processes (no heat exchange) and two isochoric processes (constant volume). The adiabatic processes are represented by the curves ab and cd. The isochoric processes are represented by the vertical lines bc and da.

In an adiabatic process, no heat is exchanged, so the work done is equal to the change in internal energy. In an isochoric process, the volume remains constant, so no work is done. The heat exchanged is equal to the change in internal energy.
The cycle starts at point a, goes to b, then to c, and finally back to a.
During the process ab, the gas expands adiabatically, doing work on the surroundings.
During the process bc, the gas is at constant volume, and heat is released.
During the process cd, the gas is compressed adiabatically, and work is done on the gas.
During the process da, the gas is again at constant volume, and heat is absorbed.
For the isochoric process bc, heat is released because the internal energy decreases.
For the isochoric process da, heat is absorbed because the internal energy increases.
The total heat absorbed during the cycle is the heat absorbed during the process da.
The total heat released during the cycle is the heat released during the process bc.
Since the cycle is a closed loop, the net work done by the gas is zero.
The heat absorbed during the isochoric process da must be equal to the heat released during the isochoric process bc to satisfy the first law of thermodynamics (energy conservation).
